subject: Real Estate
title: Redlining and Racial Segregation
description: A short lesson to help you apply Redlining and Racial Segregation.

hook.text: In the 1930s, U.S. government mapmakers colored certain neighborhoods red and labeled them 'hazardous.'

buildup.text: Banks used these maps to deny mortgages to anyone living in a red zone â€” almost always Black neighborhoods.

discovery.text: Without mortgages, residents couldn't buy homes. Without buyers, property values collapsed.

twist.text: White neighborhoods got cheap loans, built equity, and passed wealth to the next generation.

climax.text: Redlining was outlawed in 1968, but the wealth gap it created persists six decades later.

punchline.text: A red line on a map drew a wealth divide for generations.

quiz.question: What did 'redlining' prevent residents from getting?
